{% extends "_layouts/skeleton.html" %} {% set content %} # External data sources You can also use **public** external data sources (such as JSON APIs) to provide data for your prototype. The parser to be used to parse the contents of the request will be guessed from the **MIME type** of the request. If an appropriate MIME type is not set (or you wish to override it) you can also [specify the format]({{ pt.pages.getUrlById('data-formats') }}) when requesting the data in your template. To fetch data from an external source, simply use a **full URL** (including the http part) in place of a local path as the location in the [`pt.data.get()` method]({{ pt.pages.getUrlById('template-ref-data') }}#data-get). For example: {% raw %}
{% set flamingos = pt.data.get('http://api.animalz.com/flamingos') %}
{% endraw %}

Note that all external requests are sent as GET requests. Also, Prontotype does not currently support providing authentication headers of any sort, so all endpoints must be publicly available.

## Caching requests By default, all external data source requests are cached for **5 minutes**. You can override this in your [configuration file]({{ pt.pages.getUrlById('config') }}) using the following configuration block: 
cache:
  requests:
    expiry: 18000 # 5 mins
Note that the expiry time should be specified in seconds. ## Using templating logic in external data sources The body of the external request will be passed through the [Twig template parser]({{ pt.pages.getUrlById('templating-twig') }}) **prior** to having the appropriate format parser run on it. So if you are in control of the contents of the external source you can use some templating logic within it, although you can't use any `includes` or `extends` like you can in local data files. See the section on [using template logic in data files]({{ pt.pages.getUrlById('data-twig') }}) for more information. {% endset %}
